title: Tuesday, 30th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Want to know why we're six minutes late to start?

BE11:08am

In fact, that's not entirely true.

BE11:08am

It took sixteen minutes for the window to move out of "(not responding)" mode.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

One window! Nothing else happening. Zero.

BE11:09am

And to be clear, this is my desktop machine. It's not underpowered.

BE11:10am

Intel i5 7600k, by memory. I'd check that, but the act of checking it would lead my system to freeze entirely.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Why!?!!!??!?!?!!???!? I don't know why.

BE11:11am

Though the computers getting demonstrably worse has coincided with Sophos Endpoint being installed across the network.

BE11:11am

That might be a coincidence, I guess.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

I don't know. And because the machine's so damn locked down I'll never know.

BE11:12am

Anyway.

undefined
11:12 am
BE11:13am

International Consolidated Things and Stuff then.

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 599.00, down 15 (-2.44%), High: 599.50, Low: 586.36, Volume: 8.51m
BE11:14am

As the Guardian says .....

11:15 am
BE11:15am

BE11:16am

Stick the move in sterling. Always sounds dramatic.

BE11:17am

Of course, in truth, IAG moves by £500m most days on literally nothing.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Here -- eventually, sorry for the go slow but there's a literal one minute gap between me typing and the words appearing at the moment! -- is the percentage move spread chart.

BE11:18am

BE11:19am

(@Bonceur: thank you. I do need some aggressive termination in my life.)

11:19 am
BE11:19am

So, let's go through the specifics.

BE11:19am

Assuming my computer can open a PDF. Fingers crossed everyone.

BE11:20am

Citi estimates an E100m hit.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

.............. Nope. Those three minutes that just passed was the system locking up due to the effort of opening one file in Evince.

BE11:26am

Up to five minutes now.

BE11:26am

Okay, try this.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

British Airways, which accounts for c.60% of IAG’s total passenger traffic, suffered a system-wide IT failure from 11am on Saturday, 27th May, resulting in the cancellation of almost all flights for a 24 hour period plus expected disruption to many flights in the subsequent 2-3 days.

BE11:26am

We estimate c.175,000 passengers were affected by flight cancellations on 27th May and possibly more on 28th and 29th May. We estimate c.€100m total lost contribution, comprised of €40m lost revenue for one day and €60m customer compensation costs based on EU legislation. Under EU261 legislation, passengers who are delayed by more than 3 hours due to an airline’s own causes must be compensated by €250 on flights of up to 1,500 kms, €400 up to 3,000 kms and up to €600m for long-haul flights delayed by more than 4 hours. There could also be additional hotel accommodation and food/beverage costs for affected passengers.

BE11:27am

Several airlines in Europe and the US have had similar failures over the last year, which has been unfortunate but has not affected long-term revenue and earnings prospects of those companies. We believe the industry can do a better job of preparing for such situations, including better provision of back-up systems. Customer service failures in such situations are inevitable, given the negative impact on all customers at the same time.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

And RBC

BE11:27am

IAG's BA suffered yet another operational failure yesterday, this time larger than the spate of issues over the last year. As yet the cause is not known, but it is suspected to be IT hardware related according to BA statements. Coming after a spate of other issues, the bad PR and potential reputational aftermath will likely hit future revenues beyond the likely material impact on directly related costs. With already some of the lowest Skytrax (customer) and Glassdoor (staff) staff scores in the European industry, this is, in our view, a very unhelpful development for BA customers - and hence IAG shareholders.

BE11:28am

UR VIEW: It is tempting but (we think) increasingly questionable to view this as a one-off. Across IAG material operational failures seem to have become a recurring topic. This summer it is BA's IT meltdown, last year Vueling saw a much reported operational collapse over peak summer travel, compounded by reported regulatory call-ins over subsequent failure of duty of care to its customers.
An annuity of failure costs: To us the building evidence suggests that beyond the human cost, there is a building case to view related costs not as a one off, but should, with increasing probability be thought of as an annuity cost against the potential share value - at least until IAG can deliver a 'no fault' summer performance.
We think investors should await details of the real (not hypothesised problem) but if as reported this suggests fundamental management and planning weakness in BA. If (as the BA CEO has been reported by the BBC to state) it was hardware power problem, to us it seems highly questionable a why similar incidents with major US carriers in the last year have failed to see IAG move to ensure its airlines had plans in place to mitigate this risk, already seen elsewhere, and also to have contingency plans in place. At present, it appears that BA management have seemingly not taken account of IT risk precedent already seen and already known at other carriers.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

A bank like regulation 'tail risk'? Finally, airlines seem to have become a systemic part of communication and transport, and the precedent of increased regulation and oversight of legacy European banks (who have had similar high profile IT failures) suggests a small but increased regulatory risk could emerge in future.

undefined
BE11:32am

Hello! During that pause I hard-killed all versions of Chrome in the task manager.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

One of them was using 1.5 gigs. That doesn't sound right, does it?

BE11:33am

Anyway, it now feels a wee bit quicker. So hopefully now we can continue at a decent clip.

BE11:33am

Sticking to airlines ..... Should mention Ryanair.

11:33 am
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 17.98, down 0.03 (-0.17%), High: 17.99, Low: 17.25, Volume: 1.27m
BE11:34am

Travelling and arriving, to use the inevitable cliche.

BE11:35am

Results are pretty good but that was priced in, largely because O'Leary said last week at a press call in Dublin that the numbers would be strong.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Then remembered his obligations, backtracked and muttered something about them being in line and not being able to say any more.

BE11:36am

What he didn't flag up was a slightly cautious outlook.

BE11:36am

Here's UBS.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: FY 2017 revenues were €6,648m (UBS €6,724m, Cons €6,665m, FY16: €6,536m) and net income up 6% to €1,316m (UBS €1,325m, Consensus €1,315m, FY16: €1,242m). Ex fuel unit costs fell 5% and average fare fell -13% (UBS -12.5%).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Ryanair has announced a further €600m ordinary share buyback to start this week (2017: c€1bn). Ancillary revenue was up 13% and is now 27% of revenues.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: On 2018 outlook guidance is for net income of €1.4-1.45bn (UBS 1.41bn and cons 1.455bn) and maintained its traffic outlook of 130m pax. Forward bookings in H1 are reasonably robust (up 1% on prior year) but pricing remains soft. RYA expects FY18 average fares will decline by -5% to -7% (UBS -4%) and ancillary revenue per customer will likely be flat and expects ex-fuel unit cost to fall by 1% in FY18.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Shares have been strong of late but buyback should continue to provide support.

BE11:37am

And Barclays.

BE11:37am

Key points:

· Q4 results. Q4 17 net profit of €54m was inline with our estimates (€56m) and consensus (€53m). Average fares fell sharply (-19%, vs guidance of ‘up to -15%’), likely impacted by Easter shift out of March. However, this was offset by better than expected ex-fuel unit costs (-6%) and a strong ancillary performance (+3% per passenger).

· Summer outlook. Average fares are expected to fall 5% through H1, which was weaker than our estimates (-2.5%) and that of peers (for example, Wizz Air is guiding for its overall RASK to be flattish this summer). The statement stresses that Ryanair still has limited visibility over peak summer close-in pricing, and we suspect there may be some upside to the outlook here if there are less geopolitical shocks this year (last year, shorthaul pricing across the industry was damaged by a number of demand impacts through June/July including Brexit and terrorism). Ryanair is not expecting load factor to rise in FY18, but reported forward bookings +1ppt, which in theory should translate into better year-on-year pricing at some point on the yield curve. Certainly, summer should have got off to a strong start with the move of Easter into April, and we expect questions on the call about the breakdown between Q1 and Q2 average fares.

· Winter guide. Guidance suggests average fares should deteriorate to -8% in H2. Ryanair’s tradition is to incorporate a ‘worst case scenario’ winter guidance at this point in the year, and we expect the market to give it limited attention given there is no visibility. Based on the wider industry environment, there is no reason to assume a sequential decline in pricing into the winter. Furthermore, Ryanair will no longer be feeling an FX headwind, it does not appear to be ramping its growth into the winter, and Easter will partially shift back into March in 2018.

· Ancillary revenues. Ancillary revenue per passenger has performed well over the last six months, rising mid single digits at constant currency. For FY18, guidance is flat, as Ryanair works on increasing penetration of ancillaries, funded by price discounts. Key focus is on reserved seating, priority boarding and fast track security. Non-flight initiatives such as accommodation and holidays remain in early stages.

· Faster growth? Based on the outlook for legacy restructuring (Alitalia, airberlin, LOT) and its airport deal pipeline, Ryanair sees more growth opportunities than the current fleet delivery plan allows. The company is in discussion with Boeing about taking some additional 737-800s in 2018 and 2019, and is also aiming to extend 10 planned lease returns. We do not expect this to impact the FY18 growth rate, but it could take the FY19 and FY20 growth rate back to double-digit levels (currently guided to be +9% and +7% respectively). There is no change to the official fleet/growth plan today, as these discussions are still ongoing.

· Share buyback. Ryanair has announced a €600m buyback programme, to start this week and complete by the end of October. The buyback will be confined to ordinary shares. The magnitude is slightly higher than we had expected (€500m). The company is clearly now at run-rate of at least €1bn per year in shareholder returns.

11:37 am
undefined
BE11:38am

Elsewhere, Lonmin.

BE11:08am

It's because that's how long my computer took to open one Chrome window.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

So needs another rights issue, but will be in a death spiral until it actually announces it.

Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 82.50, down 3.75 (-4.35%), High: 85.25, Low: 81.75, Volume: 1.13m
BE11:39am

Today we have Peel Hunt working through that argument.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

The recovery of output from the main K3 shaft is heartening to
see. Comments that further cuts in sustaining capital would
result in reducing output, raises real concerns that from here
further cash conservation measures will start to have negative
impact on the size and scale of the business. Rolling forward the
interim results through our model sees us cut our 12-month price
target to 70p, and our recommendation moves down to Sell.

BE11:41am

(@ROTR: I run ccleaner every other evening as I leave the office. Great Suspender I find messes with logins I need to keep live.)

BE11:42am

(But thanks for the IT advice anyway.)

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Following the interim results, we moderate our production estimates slightly for FY2017E and FY2018E as the lower mine output rolls through the surface facilities. We also reset our PGM price and US$/rand assumptions in line with those used in our note, Chrome price pullback opens out the upside, published on
24 May.
The strong performance as the main K3 shaft recovered from the disputes in January means that we actually increase our FY2017E EBITDA estimate to US$18.7m from US$3.4m previously. Combined with lower capex spending, we now see a US$50m net cash closing balance sheet position.
For FY2018E, the combination of lower PGM output (we have delayed our assumed bulk tailings plant start-up) and a higher proportion of bought in concentrate means we trim EBITDA. We have also cut our estimated capex spend from US$141m to US$123m, but are nervous that a larger cut will start to drive a material fall in output in FY2019E and beyond.
We are still deeply concerned over the cash flow deficits going into the May 2020 debt maturity. Despite our rising PGM price view, we see Lonmin fully drawing its remaining credit facilities ahead of the May 2020 maturity. The building capex backlog will likely require still higher prices to reach neutral cash flows to FY2020E. Prices 12% higher than our base case and 26% higher than the current spot prices would achieve this.
Lower FY2018E cash flows mean we cut our target price to 70p from 95p previously. With some 20% downside to our revised price target, our recommendation moves from Hold to Sell. Given the anticipated cash flow deficits, a further material equity raise looks likely over the next two years.

BE11:43am

(@chopper: where was it reported?)

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Huh.

BE11:43am

Sophos Raised to Hold at Shore Capital

BE11:44am

Clearly, breaking my computer is some kind of bull signal to the folk at Shore.

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:45am

(@chopper: finger in the air stuff, by the looks of it.)

BE11:46am

While we're here, I guess we can move out of brackets though.

11:45 am
Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 403.20, up 14.2 (+3.65%), High: 406.00, Low: 378.60, Volume: 5.70m
BE11:46am

Socgen's knife catching.

BE11:46am

PFC’s market capitalisation has dropped by c.£1.2bn (c.$1.6bn) since the 12 May announcement of an investigation by the UK’s Serious Fraud Office (SFO). We view this as excessive even in the event of a very heavy fine, such as that inflicted on Rolls-Royce in Jan 2017 (£671m, o/w £479m to SFO). Using R&R’s SFO fine as a benchmark (i.e., c.4% of revenues 479/13,000) would imply a severe $320m fine for PFC. Our new 542p TP (was 1,036p) inputs a $640m fine (erring firmly on the side of caution) and a 12% WACC (was 9%) to reflect (i) increased reputational risk and a potential drop in contract awards (historically a 20-25% bid ‘hit ratio’); (ii) a change in the stock’s status as our mid–term deleveraging investment case is now postponed at best; we now forecast -$972m 2018e net debt (was -$312m). Higher financial charges result in a c.6% cut to our 2018-19 EPS estimates.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Mirabaud also cautiously knife catching.

BE11:48am

Partly on the idea of a bid, which would be absolutely heroic right now.

BE11:48am

It appears to us that Petrofac has been unfairly singled out, and that the share price reaction has been way out of proportion to any potential impact from financial penalties (IF Petrofac is found guilty) and from operational/reputational/financial risks.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

From levels of around 400p/share we believe the downside from here has to be supported by a compelling valuation and by speculative M&A potential. We suggest the quantum of any ‘remedies’ sought by the SFO would amount to no more than $500m, and that this can be easily absorbed through free cash flow, divestments or, as a last resort, suspension of the dividend.

BE11:49am

It would however be naïve of us not to assume that there is likely to be some impact on operations as a fall-out from “Unaoil-gate”, and we have amended our forecasts accordingly. We assume slower order flow, lower margins and higher financing expenses. Together these cause us to lower EPS forecasts by 1%/24%/27% across 2017-19. Our fair value for the shares drops to 800p/share. We maintain a Buy but with a Speculative rating.

BE11:50am

What can't be ignored here is the political dimension to all of this.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Theresa May has twice tried to shut down the SFO, it has been reported.

BE11:51am

(Including by the FT, if I remember correctly.)

BE11:51am

But also has the backing of the OECD

11:52 am
BE11:52am

The SFO is one of the best law enforcement agencies in the world at fighting foreign bribery. I don’t understand why someone would start questioning or changing a situation that has proven to be a good one.

BE11:52am

That's Drago Kos, Chair of the OECD Working Group on Bribery

BE11:53am

As interviewed here: http://blogs.wsj.c...success-oecd-says/

11:53 am
BE11:53am

There's not much more vicious than a regulator fighting its corner.

undefined
BE11:54am

@Pi1010, I haven't seen the Barclays gilt study but if and when I do, I'll see what can be done.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

@chopper: shush now.

BE11:56am

What else is there? All rather quiet post the long weekend.

BE11:57am

What about Ian Gordon at Investec? It's an unusual day when he's not changing his call on something.

11:57 am
BE11:58am

Yep, sure enough. OneSavings goes up to buy.

BE11:58am

OneSavings’ share price pull-back – down 9.2% since 23 May – has coincided with a share placing and fresh crop of headlines anticipating the demise of the buy-to-let market (or claims that the demise is already well underway). We suggest that this all rather misses the wood from the trees – OneSavings’ own experience points to record originations in H1 2017, improving margins and (of course) the not-so-thorny “problem” of an expanding “capital surplus” to deploy or return. We have no option but to upgrade back to BUY.

BE11:58am

We observed a recent headline on the BBC website on 17 May, “Buy-to-let slump after stamp duty change”. There is some data to “validate” this (as shown in Figure 1, page 2, aggregate volumes of buy-to-let advances for new purchases have declined since April 2016), but this data is not of any genuine relevance to OneSavings’ ambitions in the buy-to-let market. Overall, it has a c.5% share of flow, c.2/3rds of which represents remortgages.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

The reality for a specialist lender like OneSavings is, we think, entirely different from the headlines. There has been a pronounced shift in flow towards the “professional“ or “complex” end of the buy-to-let market, encouraged by regulatory intervention, which overtly works to the benefit of specialist lenders with the requisite manual underwriting capability. Both Aldermore (Buy) and Paragon (Not Rated) have similarly enjoyed a surge in new BTL originations.

Moreover, against a backdrop of increasingly competitive asset pricing in much of the UK mortgage market, OneSavings has actually been selectively increasing its pricing, (at least in the short term), in order to contain flows.

BE11:59am

That's post the Flowers selldown last week, of course.

BE11:59am

OneSavings trades on 8.9x 2017e EPS, (or just 7.4x 2019e EPS). Moreover, our forecasts currently fail to assume full deployment of its capital surplus, so additional upside potential remains. Our forecasts are 3-6% ahead of Bloomberg consensus through 2017-2019e. We upgrade to Buy (from Hold). Our (unchanged) 455p target price is reaffirmed.

12:00 pm
OneSavings Bank PLC (OSB:LSE): Last: 429.10, up 1.9 (+0.44%), High: 437.00, Low: 426.50, Volume: 198.71k
BE12:00pm

It does occur that if you follow Ian Gordon's advice, you're going to give quite a lot back on dealing commissions.

BE12:01pm

Which I guess isn't bad news for his employer.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

Somehow, we made it. The sun's nudged over the yardarm.

BE12:02pm

Thanks for sticking with. I wouldn't have bothered, quite frankly, if it weren't my job.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Euthanising this session now. Putting it out of our misery.

BE12:04pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:38am

It doesn't have enough money.
